quoteLast: submarines were reported on the starboard bow, and I personally observed the wash of a periscope, two points on our starboard bow. Immediately turned to port.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: On the first day of the New Year, these rumours took more definite shape, and on that day Her Majesty’s audience with the Grand Council lasted from
quoteTime: six to eleven in the morn
quoteLast: ing; but even then no decision had been come to in regard to complying with the demand for Chao’s execution. Throughout the neighbourhood of the Drum Tower the streets were packed with a huge crowd, who threatened that they would certainly rescue Chao if he were taken out for execution.
title: China under the Empress Dowager
author: Bland, J. O. P. (John Otway Percy), 1863-1945; Backhouse, E. (Edmund), Sir, 1873-1944

quoteFirst: On the 7th, at 5:00 p. m., she is 1° 32′ north of Saturn; on the 13th, at
quoteLast: , 5° 48′ north of the moon; and on the 26th, at 3:00 p. m., in perihelion.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, June 1885, No. 9
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: If the clergy of Ajaccio, however, have no sense of humour, they apparently understand the meaning of hard work; for I was struck by a written notice, affixed to one of the confessionals, which stated that a certain Abbé Simconi, one of the cathedral staff, attends daily here from
quoteLast: , and from 1 to 6 p.m., for the purpose of hearing the confessions of his flock. After this, no one can say that the Corsican clerics are idle.
title: A Lady's Tour in Corsica, Vol. 1 (of 2)
author: Forde, Gertrude

quoteFirst: Each of these three things may have prevented some gain. Still, on the analogy of what had happened in the first two hours, we must suppose the range at this period to have been at most about 13,000 yards. At
quoteLast: the action had reached the first rendezvous of the German submarines. They were reported to and then seen by the Admiral on his starboard bow, whereupon the squadron was turned to port to avoid them.
title: The British Navy in Battle
author: Pollen, Arthur Joseph Hungerford, 1866-1937
